thread.title: Wilson football coach Matt Senneca not interested in records after sloppy loss at Pen Argyl
thread.title_full: Wilson football coach Matt Senneca not interested in records after sloppy loss at Pen Argyl

title: Wilson football coach Matt Senneca not interested in records after sloppy loss at Pen Argyl
text:
Complete Box Score » 
It was not an afternoon to talk to Wilson head football coach Matt Senneca about records. 
It was not a day to tell Senneca that Warrior sophomore quarterback Cameron Clark had thrown for a school-record 349 yards on 20-for-35 passing. 
It was not a day to discuss with Senneca that Clark’s 93-yard touchdown strike to sophomore Job Goodman was the longest pass completion in Wilson history. 
It wasn’t a day to remind Senneca that he had said during the week that he thought the Warrior passing game was ready to step forward. 
No, it wasn’t a good day to talk to Senneca about such things. 
Because the only numbers he cared about were 49-28 – the final score of Pen Argyl’s win over the Warriors in Saturday’s Colonial League ‘up on the hill’ at Alumni Stadium in Pen Argyl. 
“I don’t look for any positives in a game we lose, especially in a game we should have been in,” Senneca said. 
Wilson (1-7), which lost to Pen Argyl (1-7) for the sixth straight season, certainly could have walked back down the hill with a triumph. 
After the Green Knights jumped out to a 12-0 first quarter lead, the Warriors roared right back to take the lead on a 21-yard TD pass from Clark to senior wide receiver Jaykwon Jefferson and a 4-yard scoring run by Goodman. 
Wilson led 13-12 with 3:51 to play before the half, owned all the momentum, and had largely silenced the Green Knights’ Homecoming crowd. 
But then the Warriors allowed a 61-yard touchdown pass to let Pen Argyl take the lead back. After that, the Warriors seemed to direct much of their fire at their own feet as the Green Knights ripped off five unanswered touchdowns helped by Wilson mistakes. 
After Logan Sterner’s 73-yard scoring run made it 43-13 late in the third quarter, the game was more or less over. 
“Once again we don’t come out and play in the second half,” Senneca said. “We came out flat and it just steamrolled from there.” 
Though Wilson didn’t go quietly; that 93-yard TD, a play on which Goodman was all by himself, couldn’t have been executed better and was worthy of a highlight film. 
Unfortunately, much of the other Warrior play was not. 
“We just keep constantly hurting ourselves,” said a furious Senneca afterwards. “Penalties, missed assignments, turnovers, mental mistakes, missed tackles. Pen Argyl didn’t do anything that we hadn’t seen on the film. But you can’t do what we did today and win games.” 
Perhaps the single most infuriating aspect of the game to Senneca came from penalties. Wilson was flagged six times for holding, several of which flags wiped out nice gains, and committed two mindless and costly personal fouls. 
“We had over 100 yards in penalties,” Senneca said. “We just keep killing ourselves.” 
Not a day to discuss records with Matt Senneca – not at all. 
Brad Wilson may be reached at bwilson@lehighvalleylive.com . Follow him on Twitter @bradwsports . Find Lehigh Valley high school sports on Facebook .
